conclusion: Identify the processes between states a and c: isochoric from a to b, adiabatic from b to c.
In an isochoric process, work done is zero, and change in internal energy equals heat added.
In an isochoric process, temperature and pressure can change, but volume remains constant.
In an adiabatic process, no heat exchange occurs, and change in internal energy equals negative work done.
In an adiabatic process, temperature and pressure can change, but entropy remains constant.
Internal energy at state b is higher than at state a due to heat added in isochoric process.
Internal energy at state c is lower than at state b due to work done in adiabatic process.
Internal energy at state c is lower than at state a.
Final Answer: The internal energy at state c is lower than the internal energy at state a.
